text: The Song of Solomon is primarily interpreted as a dialogue expressing love between whom?
options: All of the above interpretations exist
verseText: (Interpretive question about the nature of the book)

text: Who is traditionally attributed as the author of the Song of Solomon?
verseText: The Song of Songs, which is Solomon's.

text: In Song of Solomon 1:5, the woman describes herself as dark but...
verseText: I am very dark, but lovely, O daughters of Jerusalem, like the tents of Kedar, like the curtains of Solomon.

text: What does the beloved compare his lover's eyes to in Song of Solomon 1:15?
verseText: Behold, you are beautiful, my love; behold, you are beautiful; your eyes are doves.

text: In Song of Solomon 2:1, the woman compares herself to which flowers?
options: A rose of Sharon, a lily of the valleys
A tulip of the field, a daisy of the hills
A sunflower of the plains, an orchid of the mountains
A violet of the garden, a poppy of the meadow
verseText: I am a rose of Sharon, a lily of the valleys.

text: What phrase is repeated, urging the 'daughters of Jerusalem' not to awaken love until it pleases?
options: 'Do not stir up or awaken love until it pleases'
'Set me as a seal upon your heart'
verseText: I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the gazelles or the does of the field, that you not stir up or awaken love until it pleases.

text: In Song of Solomon 2:15, what are they asked to catch?
options: The little foxes that spoil the vineyards
verseText: Catch the foxes for us, the little foxes that spoil the vineyards, for our vineyards are in blossom.

text: What declaration does the woman make about her beloved in Song of Solomon 2:16?
options: 'My beloved is mine, and I am his'
verseText: My beloved is mine, and I am his; he grazes among the lilies.

text: In Song of Solomon 8:6, the woman asks her beloved to set her as what upon his heart and arm?
verseText: Set me as a seal upon your heart, as a seal upon your arm, for love is strong as death, jealousy is fierce as the grave. Its flashes are flashes of fire, the very flame of the LORD.

text: According to Song of Solomon 8:7, what cannot quench love?
verseText: Many waters cannot quench love, neither can floods drown it. If a man offered for love all the wealth of his house, he would be utterly despised.

text: What does the woman desire from her beloved in the opening verses, comparing his love to wine?
verseText: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth! For your love is better than wine;

text: Why does the woman say the 'daughters of Jerusalem' should not gaze at her because she is dark?
options: She is ashamed of her appearance
The sun has looked upon her
verseText: Do not gaze at me because I am dark, because the sun has looked upon me. My mother's sons were angry with me; they made me keeper of the vineyards, but my own vineyard I have not kept!

text: What does the beloved compare his lover to, standing out among other women, like a flower among thorns?
verseText: As a lily among brambles, so is my love among the young women.

text: How does the woman describe her beloved in comparison to other young men, using a tree metaphor?
options: Like an apple tree among the trees of the forest
verseText: As an apple tree among the trees of the forest, so is my beloved among the young men. With great delight I sat in his shadow, and his fruit was sweet to my taste.

text: What request does the woman make because she is 'sick with love'?
options: Sustain her with raisins, refresh her with apples
verseText: Sustain me with raisins; refresh me with apples, for I am sick with love.

text: What season's arrival is announced by the beloved, marked by singing birds and blossoming flowers?
verseText: for behold, the winter is past; the rain is over and gone. The flowers appear on the earth, the time of singing has come, and the voice of the turtledove is heard in our land.

text: In a nighttime search, who does the woman seek in the streets and squares of the city?
verseText: On my bed by night I sought him whom my soul loves; I sought him, but found him not. I will rise now and go about the city, in the streets and in the squares; I will seek him whom my soul loves.

text: Who does the woman encounter while searching for her beloved at night?
verseText: The watchmen found me as they went about in the city. “Have you seen him whom my soul loves?”

text: What structure did King Solomon make for himself from the wood of Lebanon, featuring silver posts and a purple seat?
verseText: King Solomon made himself a palanquin from the wood of Lebanon. He made its posts of silver, its back of gold, its seat of purple; its interior was lovingly inlaid by the daughters of Jerusalem.

text: The beloved describes his lover's hair using what pastoral image?
options: Like a flock of goats descending from Gilead
verseText: Behold, you are beautiful, my love, behold, you are beautiful! Your eyes are doves behind your veil. Your hair is like a flock of goats leaping down the slopes of Gilead.

text: What are the lover's teeth compared to?
verseText: Your teeth are like a flock of shorn ewes that have come up from the washing, all of which bear twins, and not one among them has lost its young.

text: The lover's neck is compared to what structure, adorned with shields?
verseText: Your neck is like the tower of David, built in courses; on it hang a thousand shields, all of them shields of warriors.

text: The woman is described as a 'garden locked up'. What does this metaphor likely signify?
options: Her chastity and exclusivity for her beloved
verseText: A garden locked is my sister, my bride, a spring locked, a fountain sealed.

text: What spices and perfumes are mentioned as flowing from the 'garden' (the woman)?
options: Nard, saffron, calamus, cinnamon, frankincense, myrrh, aloes
verseText: Your shoots are an orchard of pomegranates with choice fruits, henna with nard, nard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with all trees of frankincense, myrrh and aloes, with all choice spices—

text: In another nighttime scene, why does the woman hesitate to open the door for her beloved?
options: She has already washed her feet and taken off her robe
verseText: I had put off my garment; how could I put it on? I had bathed my feet; how could I soil them?

text: What fragrant spice did the beloved leave on the handles of the lock when he departed?
verseText: I arose to open to my beloved, and my hands dripped with myrrh, my fingers with liquid myrrh, on the handles of the bolt.

text: How do the 'daughters of Jerusalem' describe the beloved's appearance when the woman asks what makes him special?
options: Radiant and ruddy, distinguished among ten thousand
verseText: My beloved is radiant and ruddy, distinguished among ten thousand.

text: The beloved's head is described as the finest type of what precious metal?
verseText: His head is the finest gold; his locks are wavy, black as a raven.

text: Where has the beloved gone, according to the woman's response to the daughters of Jerusalem?
options: To his garden, to browse and gather lilies
verseText: My beloved has gone down to his garden to the beds of spices, to graze in the gardens and to gather lilies.

text: How many queens and concubines are mentioned, whom the beloved's perfect one surpasses?
verseText: There are sixty queens and eighty concubines, and virgins without number. My dove, my perfect one, is the only one, the darling of her mother, flawless to her that bore her.

text: The lover's beauty is described as awe-inspiring, like what celestial bodies or military formation?
options: Like the sun, moon, and stars
Terrible as an army with banners
verseText: You are beautiful as Tirzah, my love, lovely as Jerusalem, awesome as an army with banners.

text: What part of the lover's body is praised with the words, 'How beautiful are your feet in sandals, O prince's daughter!'?
verseText: How beautiful are your feet in sandals, O noble daughter! Your rounded thighs are like jewels, the work of a master hand.

text: The lover's navel is compared to what kind of vessel?
options: A rounded goblet never lacking mixed wine
verseText: Your navel is a rounded bowl that never lacks mixed wine. Your belly is a heap of wheat, encircled with lilies.

text: What fruit does the beloved intend to climb the 'palm tree' (the woman) to grasp?
verseText: Your stature is like a palm tree, and your breasts are like its clusters. I say I will climb the palm tree and lay hold of its fruit.

text: What invitation does the woman extend to her beloved, suggesting they go out into the fields and villages?
options: To lodge in the villages and see if the vines have budded
verseText: Come, my beloved, let us go out into the fields and lodge in the villages; let us go out early to the vineyards and see whether the vines have budded, whether the grape blossoms have opened and the pomegranates are in bloom.

text: What does the woman wish her beloved were like, so she could kiss him publicly without being despised?
options: A brother nursed at her mother's breasts
verseText: Oh that you were like a brother to me who nursed at my mother's breasts! If I found you outside, I would kiss you, and none would despise me.

text: Love is described as being as strong as what inevitable force?
verseText: Set me as a seal upon your heart, as a seal upon your arm, for love is strong as death, jealousy is fierce as the grave.

text: Jealousy (or passion) is described as being as fierce or relentless as what?
verseText: Set me as a seal upon your heart, as a seal upon your arm, for love is strong as death, jealousy is fierce as the grave. Its flashes are flashes of fire, the very flame of the LORD.

text: What would happen if someone tried to offer all their wealth in exchange for love?
options: They would be praised for their effort
verseText: Many waters cannot quench love, neither can floods drown it. If a man offered for love all the wealth of his house, he would be utterly despised.

text: In the final verses, the woman describes herself as a wall and her breasts like towers, signifying what?
options: Her maturity and readiness for marriage
Her desire to be left alone
verseText: I was a wall, and my breasts were like towers; then I was in his eyes as one who finds peace.
